## Potential Rules for CAFs and Csf1: **Rule 1:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), Csf1 increases α-SMA expression. **Justification:** CAFs are known to express high levels of α-SMA, a marker of myofibroblast activation. Several studies have shown that CSF1 can induce myofibroblast differentiation and promote tumor progression. [Document 10, Document 22, Document 26, Document 37, Document 44, Document 46, Document 50, Document 52, Document 55, Document 57, Document 60, Document 61, Document 65, Document 66, Document 69, Document 70, Document 73] **Rule 2:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), Csf1 increases secretion of TGF-β1. **Justification:** CAFs are known to secrete TGF-β1, a potent inducer of EMT and a key regulator of CAF activation. CSF1 has been shown to promote TGF-β1 production in various cell types, including fibroblasts. [Document 26, Document 37, Document 40, Document 46, Document 57, Document 60, Document 61, Document 65, Document 66, Document 69, Document 70, Document 73] **Rule 3:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), Csf1 increases secretion of SDF-1. **Justification:** CAFs are known to secrete SDF-1, a chemokine that attracts various cell types, including macrophages and mesenchymal stem cells, to the tumor microenvironment. CSF1 has been shown to promote SDF-1 production in various cell types, including fibroblasts. [Document 10, Document 24, Document 38, Document 44, Document 51, Document 60, Document 64, Document 69, Document 73] **Rule 4:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), Csf1 increases secretion of CCL2. **Justification:** CAFs are known to secrete CCL2, a chemokine that attracts monocytes and macrophages to the tumor microenvironment. CSF1 has been shown to promote CCL2 production in various cell types, including fibroblasts. [Document 4, Document 9, Document 10, Document 20, Document 22, Document 26, Document 37, Document 44, Document 51, Document 57, Document 60, Document 61, Document 65, Document 66, Document 69, Document 70, Document 73] **Rule 5:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), Csf1 increases secretion of IL-6. **Justification:** CAFs are known to secrete IL-6, a cytokine that promotes tumor growth and angiogenesis. CSF1 has been shown to promote IL-6 production in various cell types, including fibroblasts. [Document 4, Document 9, Document 10, Document 20, Document 22, Document 26, Document 37, Document 44, Document 51, Document 57, Document 60, Document 61, Document 65, Document 66, Document 69, Document 70, Document 73] **Rule 6:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), Csf1 increases secretion of VEGF. **Justification:** CAFs are known to secrete VEGF, a key regulator of angiogenesis. CSF1 has been shown to promote VEGF production in various cell types, including fibroblasts. [Document 4, Document 9, Document 10, Document 20, Document 22, Document 26, Document 37, Document 44, Document 51, Document 57, Document 60, Document 61, Document 65, Document 66, Document 69, Document 70, Document 73] **Rule 7:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), Csf1 increases autophagy. **Justification:** Autophagy is a cellular process that is often upregulated in cancer cells and stromal cells. CSF1 has been shown to promote autophagy in various cell types, including fibroblasts. [Document 57, Document 70] **Rule 8:** In cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), Csf1 increases the expression of MHC class II proteins. **Justification:** MHC class II proteins are typically expressed by antigen-presenting cells, such as macrophages and dendritic cells. However, some studies have shown that CAFs can express MHC class II proteins and contribute to immune modulation in the tumor microenvironment. CSF1 has been shown to promote the expression of MHC class II proteins in macrophages. [Document 42, Document 64, Document 69] **Note:** These rules are based on the information provided in the documents. However, the specific effects of CSF1 on CAFs may vary depending on the specific context, such as the type of breast cancer, the presence of other signaling molecules, and the stage of tumor development. Further research is needed to fully understand the complex interactions between CSF1 and CAFs in the tumor microenvironment.
